Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2009 11:11AM murphmort wrote: Hi - I finished up on June 9, 2008.  I had a lumpetcomy, no chemo.  I work full-time and have two kids (one is in college, the other high school). I took disability from work while undergoing radiation.  I couldn't focus on work and I was tired after my treatment.  I did walk everyday and made sure I ate citrus fruit (it is suppose to help while having rads), and took care of myself.  I went back to work about a month after my last treatment, and had no problem focusing.  There are days where I wonder if I'm tired because of what my body went through, or is it just being a full-time mom, wife, and holding down a job???  Who knows? I'm participating this Friday in Relay for Life at my daughter's college.  I'll walk a lap for all of you ladies!!!!!!!!!!
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2008 03:53PM murphmort wrote: I am going tomorrow to meet with the genetic counselor.  My mom was 58 when diagnosed with stage iv ovarian cancer.  I have had mammograms and CA125 tests since I was 32, and was 46 when I was diagnosed with DCIS.  My sister has her appt on 7/22.  We both want to know as we have daughters in their early 20's.  I also have to see if my insurance company will pay based on an appeal as they normally do not cover genetic testing.  We'll see what happens.  If I do get the appeal accepted and have the test, if I come back positive I will have my ovaries removed.  However, my daughter will continue to be monitored and I do not think she needs to have the testing done right now.  She will turn 20 in August and that is alot for a young kid to have to deal with.  So, I would caution her to wait a few more years, but continue the screening.  She will start having mammograms by the age of 25, and if I do test positive, or if my sister does, I would want her to have the CA125 testing done regularly. I'm going to check out the website that is referred in the postings and read up for my appt tomorrow.  Thanks for sharing all this information, ladies!
Posts.Title: BRCA test I_Run_For_Hope cdsouza

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2009 08:50AM murphmort wrote: When I received the phone call with the diagnosis and treatment plan, I knew that I had to tell my daughter who was a sophomore in college.  We told my son that night, he was a freshmen in high school.  It was parents weekend at my daughter's school, so I had a good excuse as to why I was driving down to visit her.  My daughter was active in the Students Against Cancer organization at her school and knew she would have support with the kids who are involved with that group.  It was not easy telling her, as my mom had passed from ovarian, and my daughter was close to my mom.  I kept emphasizing the positives, and I did not cry because if I did, she would never have stopped!!!    She was traveling to Europe with her school and was going to be away when I had my surgery, and I didn't want to put a damper on her trip, but I knew she would be pissed if I had not told her.   I told her the best thing she could do for me is to stay focused on her studies.  She attends a private college and received a very good merit scholarship and has to maintain a high GPA.  There is no way we could cover the costs of college w/o the scholarship.  So, she did exactly what I asked from her .... and when she came home for the Summer, she drove me to my radiation treatments in Boston and helped out with her brother (you know, all the driving around you have to do for a high school kid!).  On the last day of my treatment, I left a note on her pillow with a Breast Cancer Bracelet, thanking her for everything.  She never takes the bracelet off.  I am participating in her college's Relay for Life Event on Friday, March 27th.  I could not be prouder of those young kids, raising hundreds of thousands of dollars on that one night.  My daughter is her team's captain and their name is "Fighting Back".  I'll walk a lap for all you on March 27th. Good luck, Eliza.  I'm sorry your family has to go through this.
Posts.Title: When to tell daughter away in college Eliza2009 murphmort

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 04:23PM murphmort wrote: I would suggest you at least go to see a genetic counselor.  Knowledge is key with this disease.  I am waiting my results and wanted to know for my family.  Good luck in making the decision.
Posts.Title: Should I get tested? jojostarbuck sheddie67

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2009 01:16AM murphmort wrote: It's all so scary, when you first hear the diagnosis.  I have found this website to be so comforting and informative.  It was just about a year ago that I was so anxious and not able to sleep.  I can't believe it has been a year since the journey for me started.  It feels like it was yesterday, but other days it feels like it happened to someone else.  All of you will get through this ... it isn't easy, but with the help of this website, your friends, family and your medical professionals, you will be okay.  It's also okay to cry, to be mad, but also try and be positive.  I am forever grateful to everyone who helped me through my ordeal, and I keep thinking how lucky I am.  I only had radiation, not chemo.  Others here have a more challenging treatment plan and I wish you well. Good luck to all of you.  It's overwhelming at first, but know you can do it.
Posts.Title: I am scared -just diagnosed jancie traceyz

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 09:31AM murphmort wrote: HI ladies - I had radiation last year - 33 treatments.  I started in April and finished in June. I took disability leave from work while undergoing radiation.  My job is pretty demanding and I was finding that I could not concentrate the closer I was getting to radiation.   I went back to work full-time a month after finishing rads. I am a redhead so my skin is pretty fair.  I would put on the Aquaphor daily, so the skin wasn't too bad.  It was sore by the end, very hard to wear a seatbelt.  I did experience fatigue while having treatments and after I was finished.  I also walked several miles everyday before my treatments.  It helped so much when I was feeling down - just put some really fun tunes on your iPod and it will help!!!   Fortunately, it was the Spring so I was able to walk outside.  When I got home from rads, I would have lunch and then nap for 45 minutes.  This helped me get through the rest of the day.  I didn't want to miss anything with my kids - I never missed my son's high school baseball games.  I stopped lifting weights.  I just started lifting with the new year.  I can't lay on my stomach and sleep as I used to, but it's much better than what it was.  I also echo vivre's thoughts about eating fruits and veggies.  I had read that citrus fruits are helpful while having radiation.  I would eat fresh pineapple and oranges daily.  I also would eat salad every day.  As each month passed, I felt stronger and stronger.  I moved my daughter back to college the end of August and I know that I would not have been able to do that in July.  Having friends and family that are supportive also helps how you feel.  Rely on those people, let them help you if you need it.  Good luck to you, you'll be finished before you know it.  I kept the schedule on my frig with the % completion for each appt.  I would come home and cross off that day.  It felt good to do that. I wish you well.
Posts.Title: side effects of radiation therapy Maria217 Imasurvivor
